articles.title: Lessons from a historic quest to heal spider bites are helping to fight neglected tropical diseases today
articles.description: The bite of a black widow spider can initially feel like a sharp stabbing pain, or it can be deceptively subtle, barely registering notice. But as the spider's potent neurotoxin courses through the bloodstream, some unlucky human victims begin to develop severe symptoms. Within about an hour, the venom can cause widespread body pain, stiffness and muscle spasms, or trouble breathing.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Chemists create red fluorescent dyes that may enable clearer biomedical imaging - Phys.org
articles.description: Chemists create red fluorescent dyes that may enable clearer biomedical imaging  Phys.org
articles.source: Google News Science IN

articles.title: How enzymes 'dance' while they work, and why that's important
articles.description: Researchers from Tokyo Metropolitan University have developed a new structure determination method using nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy which shows how different parts of complex molecular machinery like enzymes move while they help catalyze reactions. The research is published in the Journal of the American Chemical Society.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Sarah Derouin
articles.title: Satellite Scans Can Estimate Urban Emissions
articles.description: As more cities strive to meet climate goals, space-based observations may help fill in the gaps on tracking emissions.
articles.source: Eos: Earth And Space Science News

articles.author: Jonathan O’Callaghan
articles.title: Planets Might Form When Dust “Wobbles” in Just the Right Way
articles.description: A liquid metal experiment has shown how magnetic rotational instability might allow dust to pool together in disks around young stars to form new worlds.
articles.source: Eos: Earth And Space Science News

articles.title: Researchers unearth origins of Ancient Egypt's Karnak Temple
articles.description: Researchers have carried out the most comprehensive geoarchaeological survey of Egypt's Karnak Temple near Luxor—one of the ancient world's largest temple complexes and a UNESCO World Heritage site welcoming millions of tourists every year.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: A 'stick-peel-reuse' adhesive based on lock-and-key chemistry
articles.description: If you have ever felt the frustration of trying to re-stick a used sticky note, you will understand the challenge of reversible adhesion. Adhesives that can strongly bond to surfaces, be peeled off, and then reused are in high demand for industrial applications.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: For 170 years, U.S. Cities have followed a hidden law of growth and decline
articles.description: Despite massive technological and industrial changes, American cities have stayed remarkably coherent in how their economies fit together. This hidden order governs how cities diversify, grow, and reinvent themselves without losing their economic identity.
articles.source: Sciencedaily

articles.title: As flight delays loom, SpaceX puts up defense in rocket vs. airplane debate
articles.description: The competition for airspace is just beginning as the space age kicks into high gear on the Space Coast.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Marine mammals are dying in record numbers along the California coast
articles.description: On a spit of sand 12 miles north of Santa Cruz, a small, emaciated sea lion lay on its side. The only sign of life was the deep press of its flippers against its belly, relaxing for a few seconds, then squeezing again.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Medicine Nobel to trio who identified immune system's 'security guards'
articles.description: A US-Japanese trio on Monday won the Nobel Prize in Medicine for research into how the immune system is kept in check by identifying its "security guards," the Nobel jury said.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Ben Pauley
articles.title: The lifecycle of a steam world
articles.description: Scientists studied exoplanets with a high water content and found that they start out with outer vapor layers, then cool and shrink over time.The post The lifecycle of a steam world appeared first on Sciworthy.
articles.source: Science For Everyone: The Latest Research Papers Explained

articles.author: Katie Grace Carpenter
articles.title: Scientists Say: Space junk
articles.description: High-velocity space junk threatens space missions today. And the problem is growing.
articles.source: Science News For Students

articles.author: Jenny Krumrine
articles.title: During heat waves, trees spew chemicals that worsen air pollution
articles.description: New data point to how heat waves and other climate change will make it harder to curb ozone and other types of toxic air pollution — even outside of cities.
articles.source: Science News For Students

articles.author: Sara Novak
articles.title: We May Know Why Ernest Shackleton’s Endurance Really Sank
articles.description: The explorer’s journey to Antarctica was likely doomed before it began.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.author: Patrick Pester
articles.title: Nobel Prize in medicine goes to trio for their work on immune tolerance
articles.description: The 2025 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine has been awarded to Mary E. Brunkow, Fred Ramsdell and Shimon Sakaguchi for work on how immune systems are prevented from attacking our own bodies.
articles.source: Live Science: The Most Interesting Articles

articles.author: Raymond Zhong and Giacomo d’Orlando
articles.title: Undersea Bacteria Feast on Methane. Can They Help Cool the Planet?
articles.description: They feast on bubbles of methane seeping out of the ocean floor. Could their appetites be harnessed to slow climate change?
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.title: Wheat diversity discovery could provide an urgently-needed solution to global food security
articles.description: Wheat has a very large and complex genome. Researchers have found that different varieties can use their genes in different ways. By studying RNA—the molecules that carry out instructions from DNA—researchers can see which genes are active and when. By mapping this gene activity for the first time, researchers are able to accelerate international wheat breeding programs, developing new varieties of wheat which can adapt to the rapidly escalating climate emergency.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: How marine heat waves reshape ocean food webs and slow deep sea carbon transport
articles.description: New research shows that marine heat waves can reshape ocean food webs, which in turn can slow the transport of carbon to the deep sea and hamper the ocean's ability to buffer against climate change.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Rocket test proves bacteria survive space launch and re-entry unharmed
articles.description: A world-first study has proven microbes essential for human health can survive the extreme forces of space launch. The study has been published in npj Microgravity.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Order from disordered proteins: Physics-based algorithm designs biomolecules with custom properties
articles.description: In synthetic and structural biology, advances in artificial intelligence have led to an explosion of designing new proteins with specific functions, from antibodies to blood clotting agents, by using computers to accurately predict the 3D structure of any given amino acid sequence.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Apt conditions found for life on Saturn’s moon - Ahmedabad Mirror
articles.description: Apt conditions found for life on Saturn’s moon  Ahmedabad MirrorCassini proves complex chemistry in Enceladus ocean  European Space AgencyScientists uncover evidence that Saturn’s moon Enceladus could have conditions suitable for life  Times of IndiaSigns of life? Why Saturn moon offers hope of finding ET in Earth’s back yard  The GuardianSaturn’s Moon Enceladus Spouts Complex Organics That Could Hold Clues to Life  Gadgets 360
articles.source: Google News Science IN

articles.title: Moon phase today: What the moon will look like on October 5 - Mashable
articles.description: Moon phase today: What the moon will look like on October 5  MashableView Full Coverage on Google News
articles.source: Google News Science US

articles.title: Vast reserves, but little to drink: Tajikistan's water struggles
articles.description: To quench his thirst, Tajik laborer Nematoullo Bassirov must take a risk—drawing water from the stream running through his yard and hoping he won't fall sick.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: The first supermoon of the year is approaching. Here's what to know
articles.description: The moon will appear slightly larger and brighter Monday night during what's known as a supermoon.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Rod McCullom
articles.title: Fresh Insights Into the Stubborn Problem of Lead Water Pipes
articles.description: The health and economic effects of lead exposure through water and lead pipes are already known. But there are still more than 9 million lead service lines across the United States, and new datasets and research methods are revealing fresh evidence of just how extensive the problem is in many cities.
articles.source: Truth Beauty Science. - Undark

articles.author: Dave Petley
articles.title: A late monsoon sting in the tale in the Himalayas
articles.description: Very heavy rainfall across Nepal, NE. India and Bhutan has triggered landslides that have killed at least 60 people. Over the last few days, parts of the Himalayas have been hit by very high levels of rainfall, causing large numbers of damaging landslides. The picture is not yet fully clear, but Nepal and Bhutan, and […]
articles.source: Eos: Earth And Space Science News

articles.title: Redefining Pharmaceutical R&D Through AI and the Digitalized Physical DMTA Cycle
articles.description: A major new two-part white paper series from ACD/Labs examines how AI-enabled design-make-test-analyze (DMTA) cycles can overcome fragmented workflows in drug discovery and development. The series discusses how pharma/biotech organizations can leverage automation and informatics technologies to digitalize workflows, empowering faster, robust, and more cost-effective innovation...
articles.source: Lab Bulletin

articles.title: Reimagine your workflows with INTEGRA’s $10,000 Future Lab Grant
articles.description: INTEGRA Biosciences is giving scientists the chance to transform their workflows with its Future Lab Grant of $10,000 to spend on the company’s cutting-edge pipetting and automation solutions. One visionary lab will win the opportunity to co-create their dream set-up, using INTEGRA’s wide range of innovative instruments, from ergonomic electronic pipettes and compact 96-channel plate fillers to accessible automation platforms...
articles.source: Lab Bulletin

articles.title: A Rogue Planet Is Growing At Record Rate Of Six Billion Tons Per Second - astrobiology.com
articles.description: A Rogue Planet Is Growing At Record Rate Of Six Billion Tons Per Second  astrobiology.comSix billion tonnes a second: Rogue planet found growing at record rate  Eso.org6 Billion Tonnes A Second! Baby Planet’s Monstrous Hunger Stuns Scientists | Watch  News18Scientists Discover Planet 620 Light-Years Away from Earth, Astonishing Researchers  Patrika NewsESO’s VLT Photographs a Rogue Planet Devouring Gas and Dust  DIYPhotography
articles.source: Google News Science IN

articles.author: Delthia Ricks
articles.title: Darleane Hoffman, Innovator in Nuclear Chemistry, Dies at 98
articles.description: Hailed as one of the 50 most important women in science, she found ways to study rare radioactive isotopes and advanced the understanding of nuclear fission.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.title: Americans, Canadians unite in battling 'eating machine' carp
articles.description: Finally, something to unite President Donald Trump, his Democratic opponents and the Canadians he's threatening to annex: a ferociously hungry carp.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Egypt reopens Amenhotep III's tomb after over 20 years of renovation
articles.description: Egypt on Saturday opened a tomb of a pharaoh for visitors after more than two decades of renovation in the southern city of Luxor, as it prepares for the official opening of the Grand Egyptian Museum in Cairo.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: If Earth had not collided with Theia 4.5 billion years ago, life would not exist - Earth.com
articles.description: If Earth had not collided with Theia 4.5 billion years ago, life would not exist  Earth.comEarth was born dry until a cosmic collision made it a blue planet  ScienceDailyEarth Was Uninhabitable Until Collision That Created The Moon "Ultimately Made Life Possible"  IFLScience“Scientists Call It Planet’s Darkest Hour”: New Research Exposes Moon Collision And Great Dying As Crucial Tests For Life  Sustainability TimesA planetary collision struck life into the Earth, reveals new study  EdexLive
articles.source: Google News Science GB

articles.title: Strange 'rogue' planet spotted guzzling matter like a star
articles.description: A mysterious "rogue" planet has been observed gobbling six billion tons of gas and dust a second—an unprecedented rate that blurs the line between planets and stars, astronomers said Thursday.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Strong friendships may literally slow aging at the cellular level
articles.description: Scientists discovered that lifelong social support can slow biological aging. Using DNA-based “epigenetic clocks,” they found that people with richer, more sustained relationships showed younger biological profiles and lower inflammation. The effect wasn’t about single friendships but about consistent connections across decades.
articles.source: Sciencedaily

articles.title: Scientists discover hidden protein that switches off hunger
articles.description: Researchers have uncovered how a protein called MRAP2 acts as a key regulator of hunger. It helps move the appetite receptor MC4R to the cell’s surface, allowing it to send stronger “stop eating” signals. The discovery offers new hope for tackling obesity by targeting this natural hunger switch.
articles.source: Sciencedaily

articles.author: Mihir Zaveri
articles.title: New York City Is Full of Green Space. You Just Have to Find It.
articles.description: The city’s millions of residents are crammed together, competing for space to live, play, work and rest.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.title: Undergrad students deploy applications to geosynchronous satellite 22,236 miles above Earth
articles.description: For many college students, satellites are faint dots crossing the sky on clear nights. These objects are background details from science fiction to reality, like GPS, satellite radio, and WiFi.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Saturday Citations: Bird news: Vultures as curators and a newly discovered interspecies warning call
articles.description: This week, researchers reported that mild dietary stress supports healthy aging. Engineers created artificial neurons that can communicate directly with living cells. And dark energy observations suggest that the universe could end in a "big crunch" at 33 billion years old.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Record-Breaking Rogue Planet Seen Growing At A Rate Of 6 Billion Tonnes Per Second - IFLScience
articles.description: Record-Breaking Rogue Planet Seen Growing At A Rate Of 6 Billion Tonnes Per Second  IFLScienceRogue planet caught behaving like a star in unprecedented observation  CNNThis rogue planet wanders space without a star. And it's started growing at a frightening rate  BBC Sky at Night MagazineExoplanet without a sun found gobbling up 6 billion tons of gas and dust per second  SpaceSix billion tonnes a second: Rogue planet found growing at record rate  ESO.org
articles.source: Google News Science US

articles.title: A tiny detector could unveil gravitational waves we’ve never seen before
articles.description: Researchers have designed a new type of gravitational wave detector that operates in the milli-Hertz range, a region untouched by current observatories. Built with optical resonators and atomic clocks, the compact detectors can fit on a lab table yet probe signals from exotic binaries and ancient cosmic events. Unlike LIGO, they’re relatively immune to seismic noise and could start working long before space missions like LISA launch.
articles.source: Sciencedaily

articles.author: Clay Risen
articles.title: Phyllis Gardner, Early Skeptic of Theranos, Dies at 75
articles.description: A pharmacologist, she was certain Elizabeth Holmes’s blood-testing idea would fail, and spoke up about it. At first, few listened.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.author: Scott Dance
articles.title: FEMA Withholds $300 Million in Grants Until States Account for Deportations
articles.description: The agency is demanding certification that population counts, used to determine grant allocations, exclude people who have been recently removed from the country.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.author: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
articles.title: U.S. Research Focus in the Arctic Shifts: Less Climate, More Security
articles.description: The Trump administration is emphasizing defense concerns instead of climate research in the rapidly warming Arctic region.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.author: Stephanie Pappas
articles.title: Did plate tectonics give rise to life? Groundbreaking new research could crack Earth's deepest mystery.
articles.description: Emerging evidence suggests that plate tectonics, or the recycling of Earth's crust, may have begun much earlier than previously thought — and may be a big reason that our planet harbors life.
articles.source: Live Science: The Most Interesting Articles

articles.title: Computational tool helps forecast volcano slope collapses and tsunamis
articles.description: For people living near volcanoes, danger goes well beyond lava flows and clouds of ash. Some explosive eruptions can lead to dramatic collapses of the sides of a volcano, like those at Mount St. Helens, Washington, and Anak Krakatau, Indonesia. The latter triggered tsunamis blamed for most deaths from its historic eruptions in 1883.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Accelerated Gulf of Maine warming may pose a serious threat to American lobsters
articles.description: The Gulf of Maine is warming faster than 99% of the world's oceans, raising concerns for its $2 billion-a-year American lobster fishery. Scientists at William & Mary's Batten School & VIMS have been studying the impacts of ocean acidification and warming on lobster reproduction, and the results of their most recent research suggest the rising temperatures pose the greatest risk.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Energy harvesters surpass Carnot efficiency using non-thermal electron states
articles.description: Harnessing quantum states that avoid thermalization enables energy harvesters to surpass traditional thermodynamic limits such as Carnot efficiency, report researchers from Japan. The team developed a new approach using a non-thermal Tomonaga-Luttinger liquid to convert waste heat into electricity with higher efficiency than conventional approaches. These findings pave the way for more sustainable low-power electronics and quantum computing.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Novel method for controlling Faraday rotation in conductive polymers
articles.description: Researchers at the University of Tsukuba have developed a novel method for controlling the optical rotation of conductive polymer polythiophene in a magnetic field at low voltage. This method combines the "Faraday rotation" phenomenon, in which a polarizing plane rotates in response to a magnetic field, with the electrochemical oxidation and reduction of conductive polymers.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Ultra-thin sodium films offer low-cost alternative to gold and silver in optical technologies
articles.description: From solar panels to next-generation medical devices, many emerging technologies rely on materials that can manipulate light with extreme precision. These materials—called plasmonic materials—are typically made from expensive metals like gold or silver. But what if a cheaper, more abundant metal could do the job just as well or better?
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Neolithic Chinese culture artifacts show systematic human bone modification
articles.description: In a recent study by Dr. Sawada and his colleagues published in Scientific Reports, 183 human bones were surveyed, of which 52 were found to be worked human bones, all of which belong to the Neolithic Liangzhu culture.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: New telescope cuts through space noise in hunt for distant Earth-like worlds
articles.description: EU researchers are developing powerful new telescopes to help uncover Earth-like planets around distant stars and advance the search for extraterrestrial life.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Millions of buildings at risk from sea level rise, analysis finds
articles.description: Sea level rise could put more than 100 million buildings across the Global South at risk of regular flooding if fossil fuel emissions are not curbed quickly, according to a new McGill-led study published in npj Urban Sustainability.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Gap-controlled infrared method enables analysis of molecular interfaces
articles.description: A novel spectroscopic method developed at Institute of Science Tokyo, Japan, enables highly sensitive analysis of molecules at material interfaces, using a combination of conventional ATR-IR, precise gap-control and advanced data processing. The technique offers a low-cost alternative to conventional interfacial spectroscopy and has potential applications in material sciences, nanotechnology, and biological sciences.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Researchers demonstrate substrate design principles for scalable superconducting quantum materials
articles.description: Silicides—alloys of silicon and metals long used in microelectronics—are now being explored again for quantum hardware. But their use faces a critical challenge: achieving phase purity, since some silicide phases are superconducting while others are not.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Fat may secretly fuel Alzheimer’s, new research finds
articles.description: New research from Houston Methodist reveals how obesity may directly drive Alzheimer’s disease. Scientists discovered that tiny messengers released by fat tissue, called extracellular vesicles, can carry harmful signals that accelerate the buildup of amyloid-β plaques in the brain. These vesicles even cross the blood–brain barrier, making them powerful but dangerous connectors between body fat and brain health.
articles.source: Sciencedaily

articles.author: Evan Roberts
articles.title: Audio Clips of Sounds of Climate Changes
articles.description: For the Climate Forward live event, we gathered recordings of a melting glacier, the Amazon jungle and the underwater Arctic, all soundscapes that are rapidly changing.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.author: Kate Golembiewski
articles.title: Ant Yogurt Is a Traditional Recipe That Crawls on 6 Legs
articles.description: Scientists recreated a formula involving ants and milk that is used in Bulgarian villages to yield yogurt with an herbaceous flavor.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.author: Anna Gora
articles.title: Our favorite budget electric toothbrush for kids is $3.79 ahead of Prime Day in October
articles.description: The Colgate Kids battery-powered toothbrush with a beloved children's character, Bluey, is 24% off at Walmart and Amazon, now just $3.79 ahead of Prime Day in October.
articles.source: Live Science: The Most Interesting Articles

articles.title: Natural barriers in northern Sweden's rivers challenge downstream assumptions
articles.description: Rivers in northern Sweden do not always become wider or richer in species further downstream. Natural barriers shape the flow and stop plants from spreading, new research from Umeå University shows. The study is published in the journal Communications Earth & Environment.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Physicists maneuver DNA molecules using electrical fields, offering real-time control
articles.description: Researchers in McGill's Department of Physics have developed a new device that can trap and study DNA molecules without touching or damaging them. The device, which uses carefully tuned electric fields, offers scientists unprecedented control over how DNA behaves in real time, creating the opportunity for faster, more precise molecular analysis that could improve diagnostics, genome mapping and the study of disease-related molecules.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Trauma in a puppy's first six months linked to adult aggression, says new study
articles.description: As many dog owners can attest, their four-legged companions are delightful and loving. But for others, their animals have an aggressive side, such as biting and attacking strangers, which may ultimately lead to them having to be euthanized. But why do some dogs turn out this way?
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Cascadia megathrust earthquake could trigger San Andreas fault
articles.description: When the tectonic subduction zone beneath the Pacific Northwest moves, it does so in dramatic fashion. Not only is ground shaking from a magnitude 9+ earthquake incredibly destructive, the event triggers tsunamis and landslides to compound the damage. Now, a new study in the Geosphere suggests the "really big one" could also trigger a major earthquake in California.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Even short school breaks can affect student learning unevenly across socioeconomic backgrounds
articles.description: The COVID-19 pandemic affected people worldwide disproportionately, with economically disadvantaged households facing a heavier burden. Children were also affected since schools and classes were closed to contain the virus.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Supercomputer modeling unlocks longstanding mystery of subducted oceanic slabs
articles.description: An international research collaboration has harnessed supercomputing power to better understand how massive slabs of ancient ocean floors are shaped as they sink hundreds of kilometers below Earth's surface.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Justin Shenolikar, Paolo Ruti and Chris Yoon Sang Chung
articles.title: The AI Revolution in Weather Forecasting Is Here
articles.description: The past decade has seen explosive growth in forecasting research and applications using AI. Sophisticated new approaches show vast potential to support public safety, health, and economic prosperity.
articles.source: Eos: Earth And Space Science News

articles.title: Counting plastic reveals hidden waste and sparks action
articles.description: Online supermarket shopping is fueling Britain's plastic waste crisis because packaging is less visible to consumers, according to new research from the Revolution Plastics Institute at the University of Portsmouth.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Around the world, migrants are being deported at alarming rates—how did this become normalized?
articles.description: Under President Donald Trump, the United States is expanding its efforts to detain and deport non-citizens at an alarming rate. In recent months, the Trump administration made deals with a number of third states to receive deported non-citizens.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Mysterious molecule found on brown dwarf casts further doubt on potential signs of life on Venus
articles.description: Brown dwarfs: too small to be stars, too big to be planets.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Why coral reefs damaged by blast fishing struggle to recover—even after decades
articles.description: When we think about rapid decline in coral reefs, climate change is often the first culprit that comes to mind—bringing heat waves, bleaching events, and intensified cyclones.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Native nectars change with climate
articles.description: New research from the University of Waikato shows how nectar supply varies with changes to climate, offering sweet insights for industry and conservation alike.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Too hot to harvest: Rising heat threatens farm labor and food security
articles.description: Imagine a farm in 2050. It's summer and solar radiation and humidity are peaking. Fruit picking machines hum and cooling mist sprays overhead. In the haze, a robot stands among the rows of fruit. It scans two strawberries—one red and ripe, the other still green. It hovers, hesitates, then makes its pick.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Anthropologist addresses artificial intelligence and the authority we give to it
articles.description: As people embrace ChatGPT and other large language models, University of Michigan anthropologist Webb Keane says it's easy for people to imbue AI with a human, or even god-like, authority.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Would cockroaches really survive a nuclear apocalypse?
articles.description: The 2008 film Wall-E depicted Earth as a post-apocalyptic wasteland with nothing on it but the abandoned remnants of human society and a forlorn, trash-compacting robot. The titular robot's only living company is a surprisingly adorable pet cockroach named Hal, Pixar's nod to the popular myth that cockroaches will outlive us all.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Humpback calves require 38 times more energy after birth
articles.description: The energy required for newborn humpback calves to grow after birth is 38 times greater than what they needed inside the womb according to research from University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa Hawaiʻi Institute of Marine Biology (HIMB) in collaboration with Alaska Whale Foundation and other key partners. These findings were published in the Marine Ecology Progress Series.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Scientists create natural plastics for everyday packaging
articles.description: Researchers have transformed food waste sugars into natural plastic films that could one day replace petroleum-based packaging, offering compostable alternatives to commonly used plastics for food and agricultural films like silage wrap.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Not all 'A's: Unconventional paths that led to Nobels
articles.description: Some Nobel laureates were straight-A students from the get-go. But others AFP spoke to recounted how they cut class, got expelled, and had doubts about their future.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: A recipe for avoiding 15 million deaths a year and climate disaster is fixing food, scientists say
articles.description: About 15 million deaths could be avoided each year and agricultural emissions could drop by 15% if people worldwide shift to healthier, predominantly plant-based diets, according to the EAT-Lancet Commission, which brought together scientists worldwide to review the latest data on food's role in human health, climate change, biodiversity and people's working and living conditions.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Marina Koren
articles.title: Two Comets Are Moving Into Your Night Skies in October: How to Watch
articles.description: The comets A6 (Lemmon) and R2 (SWAN) are visitors from the chilly fringes of our solar system, and could even be visible at the same time.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.author: Ellen Barry
articles.title: Can a Diagnosis Make You Better?
articles.description: As our diagnostic categories expand to include ever milder versions of disease, researchers propose that the act of naming a malady can itself bring relief.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.title: Birds' vocal warnings provide new insight into the origins of language
articles.description: Birds separated by vast geographic distances and millions of years of evolution share a remarkably similar learned vocal warning to identify parasitic enemies near their nests, an international team of researchers has found.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Vaccine for deadly elephant herpesvirus found safe and effective in early trial
articles.description: The world's first vaccine trial against elephant endotheliotropic herpesvirus (EEHV)—a leading cause of death in young Asian elephants—is safe and triggers a strong virus-fighting immune response, according to an international team led by the University of Surrey, in collaboration with Chester Zoo and the Animal and Plant Health Agency.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Dan Falk
articles.title: Book Review: A Call to Arms About the Threat of Anti-Science
articles.description: In “Science Under Siege,” Michael E. Mann and Peter J. Hotez launch an impassioned broadside against what they see as the attack on science from the right. “Anti-science has already caused serious illness and mass casualties in the near term. Unmitigated, it will in the long term take millions more lives.”
articles.source: Truth Beauty Science. - Undark

articles.author: Dave Petley
articles.title: The evolution of the Matai’an landslide dam
articles.description: Some excellent before and after imagery is now available showing the evolution of the Matai’an landslide dam. The active GIS/spatial analysis community in Taiwan has produced some fascinating analysis of the Matai’an landslide. Much of this has been posted to Facebook (which is not my favourite platform, but sometimes you have to go where the […]
articles.source: Eos: Earth And Space Science News

articles.title: Europa Biosite Announces Exclusive UK & Ireland Partnership between Bio X Cell and Cambridge Bioscience
articles.description: Europa Biosite is pleased to announce that Bio X Cell has appointed Cambridge Bioscience, a proud member of Europa Biosite, as its exclusive distributor for the United Kingdom and Ireland. This strategic partnership ensures that researchers across the UK and Ireland will have streamlined access to the Bio X Cell portfolio which features best-in-class functional monoclonal antibodies, globally recognized for their high quality, purity, and consistency...
articles.source: Lab Bulletin

articles.title: Beckman Coulter Life Sciences Launches Industry-First Infrared Dye Antibody Conjugates to Expand Human Phenotyping Experiments
articles.description: Beckman Coulter Life Sciences, a Danaher company and a global leader in laboratory automation and innovation, announces the launch of its new IR820 and IR870 infrared dye antibody conjugates. For the first time, research flow cytometry labs have a low noise solution, including single laser excitation, no dye interferences along with negligible overlap with other fluorochrome emissions, and ultralow autofluorescence background...
articles.source: Lab Bulletin

articles.author: Europlanet
articles.title: Mystery Ozone Surge Discovered in Mars’s Winter Darkness
articles.description: Scientists have captured rare insights into Mars’s north polar vortex, where temperatures plunge far below those outside its boundaries and darkness triggers an unusual surge in ozone. New observations of Mars’s north polar vortex during winter reveal that conditions inside it are far more extreme than those outside. The lack of sunlight at the planet’s [...]
articles.source: Scitechdaily | Science Space And Technology News 2017

articles.title: Molecular qubits can communicate at telecom frequencies
articles.description: A team of scientists from the University of Chicago, the University of California Berkeley, Argonne National Laboratory, and Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory has developed molecular qubits that bridge the gap between light and magnetism—and operate at the same frequencies as telecommunications technology. The advance, published today in Science, establishes a promising new building block for scalable quantum technologies that can integrate seamlessly with existing fiber-optic networks.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Pam Belluck
articles.title: F.D.A. Approves a New Generic Abortion Pill
articles.description: The decision enraged opponents of abortion, who have been pressuring the administration to restrict access to abortion medication.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.title: ESG ratings show limited financial impact in the Gulf, study indicates
articles.description: Firms in the Gulf region are increasingly expected to align with environmental, social, and governance (ESG) standards. Yet the link between ESG performance and financial outcomes remains ambiguous. A new study examines whether publicly listed companies in GCC member states that achieve high ESG ratings also deliver superior financial performance.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Keith Schneider
articles.title: Jane Goodall, Revered Chimpanzee Expert and Conservationist, Dies at 91
articles.description: Her discoveries as a primatologist in the 1960s about how chimpanzees behave in the wild were hailed as “one of the Western world’s great scientific achievements.”
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.title: Hurricane evacuation patterns differ based on where the storm hits
articles.description: A study comparing evacuation patterns in response to two 2024 hurricanes, Milton and Helene, found that people in coastal areas with frequent hurricane exposure were much more likely to travel out of harm's way compared to people in inland areas who were more likely to stay put.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: RAEFISH technique offers bigger and better window into RNA activity in complex tissue
articles.description: For the first time, scientists can view RNA molecules directly inside cells and tissue in minute detail and across the entire human genome concurrently, thanks to new technology created by a Yale research team.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Overlooked ubiquitin precursor promotes cellular stress resistance and longevity
articles.description: Researchers from the University of Cologne and Heinrich Heine University Düsseldorf have identified a new ubiquitin form dedicated to proteostasis and healthy aging. They show that CxUb (C-terminally extended ubiquitin), is necessary and sufficient to overcome stress, a discovery that opens up new routes for the treatment of cancer and aging-related diseases.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Study shows the world is far more ablaze now with damaging fires than in the 1980s
articles.description: Earth's nastiest and costliest wildfires are blazing four times more often now than they did in the 1980s because of human-caused climate change and people moving closer to wildlands, a new study found.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Mapping RNA-protein 'chats' could uncover new treatments for cancer and brain disease
articles.description: Bioengineers at the University of California San Diego have developed a powerful new technology that can map the entire network of RNA-protein interactions inside human cells—an achievement that could offer new strategies for treating diseases ranging from cancer to Alzheimer's.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: When it comes to storing carbon, the Arctic presents a winter surprise
articles.description: The ocean holds gigantic amounts of carbon, much more than all land-based plants and soil. Scientists previously studied these carbon stocks in spring and summer. Now, in two published studies, they have looked at what happens in winter.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Brewing resilience: Researchers safeguard coffee and chocolate from climate threats
articles.description: From droughts to disease, coffee and chocolate are under threat, but scientists and farmers are working together to keep these daily treats on the table.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Patrick Pester
articles.title: HPV vaccination drives cervical cancer rates down in both vaccinated and unvaccinated people
articles.description: Researchers have found that human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccines are highly effective at reducing cervical cancer-causing infections and can offer herd immunity, reinforcing previous research and highlighting the need for a global HPV vaccine rollout.
articles.source: Live Science: The Most Interesting Articles

articles.title: Designing random nanofiber networks, optimized for strength and toughness
articles.description: In nature, random fiber networks such as some of the tissues in the human body, are strong and tough with the ability to hold together but also stretch a lot before they fail. Studying this structural randomness—that nature seems to replicate so effortlessly—is extremely difficult in the lab and is even more difficult to accurately reproduce in engineering applications.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Silver-nanoring coating points to 'self-regulating' smart windows—without power or tinting
articles.description: A new Danish research breakthrough could make buildings far more energy-efficient in the future. Researchers from Aarhus University's Interdisciplinary Nanoscience Center (iNANO) have developed a light-responsive hybrid material based on so-called silver nanorings that automatically responds to solar intensity and regulates how much heat penetrates through windows.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Opinion: American TikTok deal doesn't address the platform's potential for manipulation, only who profits
articles.description: On Sept. 25, the Donald Trump administration in the United States again extended the TikTok ban-or-divest law, possibly for the last time. The latest extension to the law, which was passed in 2024 by the Joe Biden administration, includes a deal to transfer TikTok to American owners as a condition required to avoid a ban.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: New radioactive isotope therapies promise more targeted attacks on cancer
articles.description: Recent clinical successes, and profits, have prompted a rush among pharma companies to try new isotopes and targeting strategies
articles.source: Science | Aaas

articles.title: A picture is worth a thousand words: Multimedia slides help students boost science vocabulary
articles.description: Using pictures to help middle school students visualize science terms could be the key to boosting vocabulary for all students, including those with learning disabilities who struggle with reading and writing.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Rebecca Dzombak
articles.title: Costly and Deadly Wildfires Really Are on the Rise, New Research Finds
articles.description: The past decade in particular has seen an uptick in devastating blazes linked to climate change, according to the study.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.title: Fossilized ear bones rewrite the history of freshwater fish
articles.description: When saltwater fish long ago evolved to live in fresh water, many of them also evolved a more sophisticated hearing system, including middle ear bones similar to those in humans.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Marine scientists urge overhaul of restoration rules to save oceans
articles.description: Swansea University has led an international team of marine scientists and practitioners—spanning 18 countries—in calling for urgent reform to the licensing and regulation of marine and coastal restoration projects.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Money can buy cooperation, but deep-seated biases remain stubbornly unchanged
articles.description: In business, marketing and social work, financial incentives are often used to increase people's motivation, guide their behavior and achieve lasting success. However, the latter is not always the case, as a recent study in Royal Society Open Science by the University Hospital of Würzburg (UKW) shows. Prof. Dr. Grit Hein and her team at the Center for Translational Social Neuroscience at the Center for Mental Health (ZEP) investigated whether people from a particular group would approach a foreign group if they received money for doing so.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Unexpected region of the Amazon is experiencing 'alarming' rapid growth in climate extremes
articles.description: An unexpected region of the Amazon is at the forefront of rapid growth in climate extremes, a new report reveals. The central north Amazon, a region with extensive areas of high forest cover, natural savannas and vast Indigenous territories, was not previously considered as being the most affected by climate change.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: USS Arizona provides blueprint for addressing oil leakage at thousands of WWII shipwrecks
articles.description: A new study published in Marine Pollution Bulletin shows that oil is still seeping from the wreck of the USS Arizona, more than 80 years after its sinking at Pearl Harbor. The study focuses on samples collected by the National Park Service in 2016 and 2018.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Quantum key distribution method tested in urban infrastructure offers secure communications
articles.description: In the era of instant data exchange and growing risks of cyberattacks, scientists are seeking secure methods of transmitting information. One promising solution is quantum cryptography—a quantum technology that uses single photons to establish encryption keys.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Political views, not sex and violence, now drive literary censorship
articles.description: Liberals and conservatives both oppose censorship of children's literature—unless the writing offends their own ideology, new Cornell research finds.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: 'Nanoreactor' cage uses visible light for catalytic and ultra-selective cross-cycloadditions
articles.description: Researchers have engineered a novel M6L4 octahedral molecular cage by integrating photoactive cyclometalated platinum(II) units, creating a visible-light-responsive "nanoreactor" that drives highly efficient photochemical reactions through precise molecular confinement. This innovative design overcomes the limitations of previous hosts, achieving perfect stereo- and site-selective cross-[2 + 2] cycloaddition reactions, and most notably, enabling catalytic cross-[2 + 2] cycloaddition of chemically inert substrates using this supramolecular confinement approach.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Sascha Pare
articles.title: Wildfire-smoke-related deaths in the US could climb to 70,000 per year by 2050 due to climate change, study finds
articles.description: The number of deaths from exposure to wildfire smoke in the U.S. could rise by more than 70% in the next 25 years. The human and economic costs involved would be astronomical, researchers say.
articles.source: Live Science: The Most Interesting Articles

articles.title: Anglers delight in salmon returns, but study warns of coho population collapse
articles.description: While anglers are celebrating a strong start to the salmon season, a new Simon Fraser University study warns coho salmon are under serious threat.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: What to know about the life and legacy of chimpanzee researcher and wildlife advocate Jane Goodall
articles.description: Famed primatologist Jane Goodall was renowned for her groundbreaking work with chimpanzees but dedicated her life to helping all wild animals—a passion that lasted until her death this week while on a U.S. speaking tour.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: AI techniques excel at solving complex equations in physics, especially inverse problems
articles.description: Differential equations are fundamental tools in physics: they are used to describe phenomena ranging from fluid dynamics to general relativity. But when these equations become stiff (i.e. they involve very different scales or highly sensitive parameters), they become extremely difficult to solve. This is especially relevant in inverse problems, where scientists try to deduce unknown physical laws from observed data.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Brad Plumer and Maxine Joselow
articles.title: Energy Dept. Cancels Hundreds of Clean-Energy Projects, Mostly in Blue States
articles.description: The cuts almost entirely affect Democratic-led states as the two parties fight over the shutdown of the federal government.
articles.source: The New York Times

articles.title: How VR and AI could help the next generation grow kinder and more connected
articles.description: Empathy is not just a "nice-to-have" soft skill—it is a foundation of how children and adults regulate emotions, build friendships and learn from one another.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Nature's not perfect: Fig wasps try to balance sex ratios for survival but they can get it wrong
articles.description: Television nature programs and scientific papers tend to celebrate the perfection of evolved traits. But the father of evolution through natural selection, Charles Darwin, warned that evolution would produce quirks and "blunders" that reflect a lineage's history.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: The spiritual and emotional world of pub psychic nights
articles.description: At a Bristol social club, a psychic medium scans the room, inviting the spirit world into a space more often used for drinking and darts. The medium is talking to a small audience, mostly women.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Meet Irene Curie, the Nobel-winning atomic physicist who changed the course of modern cancer treatment
articles.description: The adage goes "like mother like daughter," and in the case of Irene Joliot-Curie, truer words were never spoken. She was the daughter of two Nobel Prize laureates, Marie Curie and Pierre Curie, and was herself awarded the Nobel Prize in chemistry in 1935 together with her husband, Frederic Joliot.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Specialized teachers can make mainstream schools better for children with special educational needs
articles.description: Most pupils who go through the lengthy process of being identified with dyslexia, autism or another condition end up spending the bulk of their time supported not by a trained specialist teacher but by a teaching assistant.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Study shows how circular RNA is preferentially packaged for transport between cells
articles.description: It's no secret that we need new ways to treat and detect disease, including cancer. Specifically, we need better biomarkers that can be used for diagnosis and better ways to selectively get medicine where we want it to go in the body.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Government investment lifted young people's hopes in 'left behind' areas, new research shows
articles.description: Young people growing up in England's most disadvantaged areas are feeling more hopeful about their future study and work prospects thanks to targeted Government investment, according to new research from the Universities of Bath, Bristol and Durham.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Turning microalgae into a sustainable high protein food solution
articles.description: As climate change and a growing global population strains our existing food supply, scientists are looking on land and at sea for innovative solutions.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Sophie Berdugo
articles.title: Scientists find best evidence yet that icy moon Enceladus is habitable
articles.description: An ocean flowing beneath the surface of Saturn's moon Enceladus is spewing ice that holds the building blocks of life.
articles.source: Live Science: The Most Interesting Articles

articles.title: White Rabbit optical timing technology meets quantum entanglement
articles.description: A small yet innovative experiment is taking place at CERN. Its goal is to test how the CERN-born optical timing signal—normally used in the Laboratory's accelerators to synchronize devices with ultra-high precision—can best be sent through an optical fiber alongside a single-photon signal from a source of quantum-entangled photons. The results could pave the way for using this technique in quantum networks and quantum cryptography.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Volcanic ash may enhance phytoplankton growth in the ocean over 100 km away
articles.description: A research group in Japan has suggested that ash released from volcanic eruptions on Nishinoshima Island—part of Japan's Ogasawara Islands—led to a temporary surge in phytoplankton levels in the seawater around Mukojima Island, which is located 130 km northeast of Nishinoshima and is also part of the Ogasawara Islands.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Interstellar comet swinging past Mars as a fleet of spacecraft looks on
articles.description: A comet from another star system will swing by Mars on Friday as a fleet of spacecraft trains its sights on the interstellar visitor.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Finding buried treasures with physics: 'Fingerprint matrix' method uncovers what lies beneath the sand
articles.description: Can we reveal objects that are hidden in environments completely opaque to the human eye? With conventional imaging techniques, the answer is no: a dense cloud or layer of material blocks light so completely that a simple photograph contains no information about what lies behind it.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Port Canaveral preps for more rocket recoveries with third crane
articles.description: Port Canaveral has had such a busy year supporting SpaceX's rocket recovery efforts, it brought in a new crane to assist in the launch parade on the Space Coast.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: How lemurs are laying the groundwork for interstellar travel
articles.description: October is Space Month. At Duke University, space research is more than just science—it's a bold journey across disciplines. This is the first in a series of stories featuring innovators, dreamers and doers shaping the future of the exploration of the cosmos.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Poor sleep speeds brain aging and may raise dementia risk
articles.description: New research shows that poor sleep could make the brain appear years older than it really is. Using MRI scans and machine learning, scientists found a clear link between unhealthy sleep patterns and accelerated brain aging.
articles.source: Sciencedaily

articles.title: 'Only if we help shall all be saved': Jane Goodall showed we can all be part of the solution
articles.description: With the passing of Dr. Jane Goodall, the world has lost a conservation giant. But her extraordinary achievements leave a profound legacy.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Do ID cards help stop undocumented migrants from finding work?
articles.description: One of the U.K.'s biggest political problems comes in a small size. The size of a small boat, in fact.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Kaja Šeruga
articles.title: Old Forests in the Tropics Are Getting Younger and Losing Carbon
articles.description: New research quantifying the global impact of forest age transitions found that 140 million tons of aboveground carbon are lost per year because of old-growth forests being replaced by younger stands.
articles.source: Eos: Earth And Space Science News

articles.title: Ice mixed with amino acids stores methane in minutes
articles.description: If you have ever cooked on a gas stove or seen a flame flicker to life with the turn of a knob, you have seen natural gas in action. Supplying that energy at scale, however, is far more complicated. Today, natural gas is mostly stored under high pressure or cooled into liquid at -162°C—both methods that are energy-intensive and costly.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Rogue planet gains 6 billion tonnes per second in record growth spurt
articles.description: A free-floating planet has been seen devouring astonishing amounts of matter, hinting that stars and planets are more alike than we thought
articles.source: New Scientist Magazine

articles.title: Tories pledge to scrap landmark climate legislation
articles.description: Conservative leader Kemi Badenoch says her party would axe legally binding targets to cut emissions.
articles.source: BBC News - Science & Environment

articles.title: Six billion tons a second: Rogue planet found growing at record rate
articles.description: Astronomers have identified an enormous "growth spurt" in a so-called rogue planet. Unlike the planets in our solar system, these objects do not orbit stars, free-floating on their own instead. The new observations, made with the European Southern Observatory's Very Large Telescope (ESO's VLT), reveal that this free-floating planet is eating up gas and dust from its surroundings at a rate of six billion tons a second. This is the strongest growth rate ever recorded for a rogue planet, or a planet of any kind, providing valuable insights into how they form and grow.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Two highly scattered pulsars discovered with ASKAP
articles.description: Astronomers report the discovery of two new highly scattered pulsars as part of the Australian SKA Pathfinder (ASKAP) Variables and Slow Transients (VAST) survey. The findings are detailed in a research paper published September 24 on the arXiv preprint server.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Inside the lab analysing the world's oldest ice
articles.description: The BBC's Science Editor Rebecca Morelle goes behind the scenes with the team discovering what the melting of ice from over a million years ago can tell us.
articles.source: BBC News - Science & Environment

articles.title: Rare glimpse at understudied ecosystem prompts caution on deep-sea mining
articles.description: An enormous but poorly understood region of the global ocean—referred to as the abyssal benthic boundary layer—lies a few meters above the seafloor and has only been sampled a handful of times. A study by oceanographers at the University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa provided the first in-depth look at this habitat, revealing a dynamic community that may be more sensitive to seasonal changes than previously understood.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.title: Improved fertility diagnostics could boost bird conservation breeding programs, say scientists
articles.description: A new analytical method is revealing how conservationists can further boost breeding programs dedicated to saving some of the world's most threatened species, according to new research led by the University of Sheffield and ZSL.
articles.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

articles.author: Sarah Zielinski
articles.title: Explainer: What is a shark?
articles.description: These fish have skeletons made of cartilage, not bone — and aren’t nearly as scary as portrayed in the media.
articles.source: Science News For Students

articles.author: Brianna Randall
articles.title: Save the sharks to save the ocean
articles.description: Humans have driven sharks and their cousins to the brink of extinction, but it’s not too late to turn the tide. At stake is the health of the entire ocean.
articles.source: Science News For Students

articles.title: Proof Of Complex Organic Molecules In Enceladus’s Ocean: “You Have Everything You Need To Form Life” - IFLScience
articles.description: Proof Of Complex Organic Molecules In Enceladus’s Ocean: “You Have Everything You Need To Form Life”  IFLScienceDetection of organic compounds in freshly ejected ice grains from Enceladus’s ocean  NatureCassini proves complex chemistry in Enceladus ocean  European Space AgencyNew study adds to the possibility of favorable conditions for life at Saturn’s moon Enceladus  AP NewsProspect of life on Saturn’s moons rises after discovery of organic substances  The Guardian
articles.source: Google News Science US

articles.title: Cassini proves complex chemistry in Enceladus ocean - European Space Agency
articles.description: Cassini proves complex chemistry in Enceladus ocean  European Space AgencyDetection of organic compounds in freshly ejected ice grains from Enceladus’s ocean  NatureProspect of life on Saturn’s moons rises after discovery of organic substances  The GuardianSaturn moon may contain life  The Telegraph‘Organic molecules’ are coming out of a nearby moon that could be home to aliens, scientists say  The Independent
